abstract.text: A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects encapsulate a single point in time, independent of any particular calendrical system or time zone. Date objects are immutable, representing an invariant time interval relative to an absolute reference date (00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 2001).
The
class provides methods for comparing dates, calculating the time interval between two dates, and creating a new date from a time interval relative to another date.
objects can be used in conjunction with
objects to create localized representations of dates and times, as well as with
objects to perform calendar arithmetic.
is
toll-free bridged
with its Core Foundation counterpart,
. See
for more information on toll-free bridging.
The Swift overlay to the Foundation framework provides the
structure, which bridges to the
class. For more information about value types, see
in
You might subclass
in order to make it easier to work with a particular calendrical system, or to work with date and time values with a finer temporal granularity.

content.text: Methods to Override and Other Requirements

inlineContent.text: If you want to subclass
to obtain behavior different than that provided by the private or public subclasses, you must:
Declare a suitable instance variable to hold the date and time value (relative to an absolute reference date)
Override the
instance method to provide the correct date and time value based on your instance variable
Override
, one of the designated initializer methods
If creating a subclass that represents a calendrical system, define methods that partition past and future periods into the units of this calendar
Implement the methods required by the
and
protocols, because
adopts these protocols
Your subclass may use a different reference date than the absolute reference date used by
(00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 2001). If it does, it must still use the absolute reference date in its implementations of the methods
and
. That is, the reference date referred to in the titles of these methods is the absolute reference date. If you do not use the absolute reference date in these methods, comparisons between
objects of your subclass and
objects of a private subclass will not work.

abstract.text: An alias for this value type's equivalent reference type.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Returns a date object initialized with a date and time value specified by a given string in the international string representation format.
The interval between the date object and 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970.
Creates and returns a date object set to the date and time specified by a given string.
Converts the receiver to a calendar date with a given format string and time zone.
The interval between the date object and the current date and time.
The interval between 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 2001 and the current date and time.
Creates and returns a date object with a date and time value specified by a given string in the international string representation format (
Returns a new date object that is set to a given number of seconds relative to the receiver.
Returns the later of the receiver and another given date.
Indicates the temporal ordering of the receiver and another given date.
A string representation of the date object.
Returns a date object initialized relative to 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 2001 by a given number of seconds.
Returns the interval between the receiver and another given date.
Returns a date object initialized relative to the current date and time by a given number of seconds.
Returns a date object initialized from data in the given unarchiver.
Returns the earlier of the receiver and another given date.
Returns a string representation of the date using the given locale.
Returns a date object initialized relative to another given date by a given number of seconds.
A date object representing a date in the distant future.
Returns a date object initialized to the current date and time.
Creates and returns a date object set to the date and time specified by a given string.
Returns a string representation of the date formatted as specified by given conversion specifiers.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a given object is a date that is exactly equal the receiver.
Returns a date object initialized relative to 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970 by a given number of seconds.
The interval between the date object and 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 2001.
A date object representing a date in the distant past.
Returns a new date object that is set to a given number of seconds relative to the receiver.
A custom playground Quick Look for this object.
The current date and time, as of the time of access.
A notification posted whenever the system clock is changed.
The number of seconds from 1 January 1970 to the reference date, 1 January 2001.
